Description: The SEC announced enforcement and disciplinary actions against a total of 15 firms for failure to deliver mutual fund breakpoint discounts during 2001 and 2002.

American Express Financial Advisors Inc., now known as Ameriprise Financial Services, Inc., agreed to pay $30 million to settle allegations that it failed to adequately disclose millions of dollars in revenue sharing payments that it received from a select group of mutual fund companies.

American Express Financial Corporation, now known as Ameriprise Financial, Inc. agreed to pay $15 million to settle allegations that it acted contrary to prospectus disclosures when it allowed certain shareholders to market time the mutual funds it advised.

While not admitting liability, Ameriprise Financial, Inc. agreed to pay a total of $128,200 in back wages and interest to 20 black employees in unlicensed service professional positions, after an OFCCP compliance review found the company violated Executive Order 11246 by paying black employees who processed routine account service requests less than their similarly situated white counterparts.
Agency: Office of Federal Contract Compliance Programs

Description: Ameriprise Financial Services, Inc. agreed to pay $17.3 million to settle allegations that it received millions of dollars in undisclosed compensation as a condition for offering and selling certain real estate investment trusts (REITs) to its brokerage customers.

Company: Columbia Management Advisors Inc. and Columbia Funds Distributor Inc.
Description: Columbia Management Advisors Inc. and Columbia Funds Distributor Inc. agreed to pay $140 million to settle allegations of undisclosed market timing arrangements.

The SEC sanctioned 13 firms for violating a rule primarily designed to protect retail investors in the municipal securities market. In its surveillance of trading in the municipal bond market, the SEC Enforcement Division's Municipal Securities and Public Pensions Unit detected improper sales below a $100,000 minimum denomination set in a $3.5 billion offering of junk bonds by the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico.
overtime violation

Court: District of the District of Columbia
Private Litigation Case Title: Kosen et al v. American Express Financial Advisors Inc. et al
Krueger et al v. Ameriprise Financial, Inc. et al

Description: Ameriprise Financial Services agreed to pay $200,000 in settlement of allegations some employees engaged in unfair and deceptive practices while working as financial advisors, including charging customers for undelivered financial plans, failing to disclose fees for financial plans, forging client signatures on transactions, and selling unsuitable mutual funds and insurance products.
The RiverSource subsidiaries of Ameriprise agreed to pay $1.5 million to settle multistate litigation regarding the use of the Social Security Administration's Death Master File.
Info Source: $1.5 Million Life Claim Settlement Reached with Ameriprise Group, States News Service, January 30, 2017 (via Nexis).

Description: Ameriprise agreed to pay a $1,000,000 administrative penalty in settlement of allegations it failed to reasonably supervise its registered securities salesmen, leading to customers being defrauded.
Ameriprise agreed to pay a $1,250,000 administrative penalty in settlement of allegations it failed to reasonably supervise its registered securities salesmen, leading to customers being defrauded.

RiverSource agreed to pay a $800,000 administrative penalty in settlement of allegations that its claims handling procedures for life, accident, disability and long term care insurance did not comply with state regulations.
Ameriprise agreed to pay $115,000 in settlement of allegations it failed to supervise sales of securities resulting in sales to unsuitable investors.
Agency: California Department of Financial Protection and Innovation

Description: Ameriprise agreed to pay a $75,000 fine and offer $1,374,384 in restitution in settlement of allegations it failed to adequately supervise an investment advisor accused of defrauding customers.

Ameriprise agreed to pay a $300,000 penalty, a $100,000 contribution to the state Investor Protection Trust, $50,000 in costs, and $533,984 in restitution in settlement of allegations it engaged in dishonest treatment of investment clients and failed to supervise two of its agents who were alleged to have committed multiple securities violations.

American Express Financial Advisors agreed to pay a $2 million civil penalty to the state in settlement of allegations it failed to establish and maintain supervision policies of employees and failed to check suitability of mutual fund shares purchased, leading to some transactions occuring where mutual fund shares were recommended or purchased based on brokerage commissions instead of suitability for the customer.
Notes: Order notes that this action is in addition to the SEC and NASD investigations because Minnesota is the company's domicile state and primary state regulator.

Description: failure to disclose conflicts of interest in investment advisory services
Agency: New Hampshire Bureau of Securities Regulation

Description: The Bureau alleged Ameriprise failed to live up to its obligations under a 2005 settlement (at which time it was known as American Express Financial Advisors).
Agency: New Hampshire Bureau of Securities Regulation
New Hampshire Bureau of Securities Regulation
New Hampshire Bureau of Securities Regulation
New York Department of Financial Services
Rhode Island Department of Business Regulation

Description: failure to prevent the marketing of unsuitable investments by registered representatives

Agency: Washington State Department of Financial Institutions

Description: Ameriprise agreed to pay a total of $720,000 to regulators in Alabama and Georgia to resolve a case of a company representative accused of dishonest practices.
RiverSource agreed to pay $1.5 million to settle multistate litigation regarding their use of the Social Security Administration's Death Master File.

The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority fined Ameriprise Financial Services, Inc. $850,000 for failing to detect the conversion of more than $370,000 from five customer brokerage accounts by one of its registered representatives.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority fined Ameriprise Financial Services, Inc. and its affiliated clearing firm, American Enterprise Investment Services Inc. (AEIS), $750,000 for failing to have reasonable supervisory systems in place to monitor wire transfer requests and the transmittal of customer funds to third-party accounts.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government.

Description: NASD fined Ameriprise Financial Services, Inc. $12.3 million in connection with its receipt of directed brokerage in return for providing preferential treatment to certain mutual fund companies.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Description: NASD ordered Ameriprise Financial Services, Inc.  to pay a fine of $500,000 for failing to adequately supervise the firm's sales of 529 plans. NASD also ordered the firm to pay approximately $750,000 to compensate more than 500 customer accounts disadvantaged by those supervisory failures.
Info Source: NASD Fines Ameriprise Financial Services, Inc. $500,000 for Supervisory Violations in 529 College Savings Plan Sales, PR Newswire, October 26, 2005 (via Nexis).
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Description: NASD censured and fined Citigroup Global Markets, Inc., American Express Financial Advisors, and Chase Investment Services a total of $21.25 million for suitability and supervisory violations relating to mutual fund sales practices between January 2002 and July 2003.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Description: NASD censured and fined 29 securities firms over $9.2 million for more than 8,000 late disclosures of reportable information about their brokers, including customer complaints, regulatory actions, and criminal charges and convictions.
Info Source: NASD Fines 29 Firms over $9.2 Million for Late Reporting, PR Newswire, November 30, 2004 (via Nexis).
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Description: NASD fined three securities firms and one broker a total of $503,000 for violations involving variable annuity transactions.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).

Description: NASD censured and fined American Express Financial Advisors Inc. $350,000 for sales practice and supervision violations in connection with its sale of variable annuities and variable life insurance products over a 30 month period, ending in 2000.
Notes: FINRA is a securities industry self-regulatory body authorized by the federal government. This case was handled by its predecessor, the National Association of Securities Dealers (NASD).
